unnormalised: AIIMS Delhi, known for its top-notch neuro department, saw a hilarious case this week. A man from Ghaziabad, let’s call him Mr. Sharma (not his real name, because, you know, patient confidentiality and all that jazz), came in complaining of “brain farts” after binge-watching 24 hrs of saas-bahu serials.
normalised: A-I-I-M-S Delhi, known for its top-notch neuro department, saw a hilarious case this week. A man from Ghaziabad, let’s call him Mister Sharma (not his real name, because, you know, patient confidentiality and all that jazz), came in complaining of “brain farts” after binge-watching twenty four hours of saas-bahu serials.

unnormalised: Dr. Gupta, Head of Neurology, initially suspected a rare neurological condition, maybe some variant of "Bigg Boss Brain Drain," but after a thorough MRI scan (cost: ₹7000, because nothing is cheap these days, not even scanning your brain), it turned out to be a severe case of… information overload. Apparently, too much melodrama had fried his circuits!
normalised: Doctor Gupta, Head of Neurology, initially suspected a rare neurological condition, maybe some variant of "Bigg Boss Brain Drain," but after a thorough M-R-I scan (cost: rupee seven thousand, because nothing is cheap these days, not even scanning your brain), it turned out to be a severe case of… information overload. Apparently, too much melodrama had fried his circuits!

unnormalised: The doctor, bless his heart, prescribed a strict diet of news channels and documentaries. “No more kitchen politics for you, Sharma ji,” he said, chuckling. Dosage: 1 hr of BBC News followed by 30 mins of Nat Geo. Side effects may include newfound interest in geopolitics and a sudden urge to explain string theory at family gatherings.
normalised: The doctor, bless his heart, prescribed a strict diet of news channels and documentaries. “No more kitchen politics for you, Sharma ji,” he said, chuckling. Dosage: one hour of B-B-C News followed by thirty minutes of Nat Geo. Side effects may include newfound interest in geopolitics and a sudden urge to explain string theory at family gatherings.

unnormalised: “We’ve seen cases of video game-induced seizures and even ‘Facebook frenzy’ leading to anxiety, but this… this is a first,” Dr. Gupta admitted, scratching his head. “I might write a paper on it. Title: ‘The Curious Case of the Serial-Fried Brain’.”
normalised: “We’ve seen cases of video game-induced seizures and even ‘Facebook frenzy’ leading to anxiety, but this… this is a first,” Doctor Gupta admitted, scratching his head. “I might write a paper on it. Title: ‘The Curious Case of the Serial-Fried Brain’.”

unnormalised: Mr. Sharma, now recovering in Ward 6 (next to the guy who thinks he's Shah Rukh Khan), says he's already feeling better. "At least now I know what 'breach of contract' means, instead of just assuming it's what happens when Tulsi betrays Mihir," he quipped, sipping his chai.
normalised: Mister Sharma, now recovering in Ward six (next to the guy who thinks he's Shah Rukh Khan), says he's already feeling better. "At least now I know what 'breach of contract' means, instead of just assuming it's what happens when Tulsi betrays Mihir," he quipped, sipping his chai.

unnormalised: AIIMS has issued an advisory: Limit your daily dose of daily soaps to 2 episodes, max. And if you start seeing talking animals or hearing background music when you walk into a room, seek immediate medical attention. Your brain might be trying to escape. Consultation fee: Rs. 500. Bargaining not allowed.
normalised: A-I-I-M-S has issued an advisory: Limit your daily dose of daily soaps to two episodes, max. And if you start seeing talking animals or hearing background music when you walk into a room, seek immediate medical attention. Your brain might be trying to escape. Consultation fee: rupees five hundred. Bargaining not allowed.

unnormalised: It also reminds that its neuro OPD is open on weekdays from 9:00 AM to 5:00 PM.
normalised: It also reminds that its neuro O-P-D is open on weekdays from nine A-M to five P-M.
